title: 'I died 27 times in 24 hours': Miracle dad's incredible tale of survival thanks to dedicated NHS staff
text:
Ray Woodhall, 54, felt a sharp chest pain while playing 'walking football' (Photo: Facebook) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A dad who 'died' 27 times in 24 hours has told of his incredible survival thanks to dedicated NHS staff. 
Ray Woodhall, 54, collapsed while playing 'walking football' after suffering a heart attack. 
He was rushed to hospital but had a further 26 attacks. 
Somehow he is still here to tell the tale, thanks to the top cardiology team at Worcestershire Royal Hospital. 
Ray told The Sun: "They told me they’ve never heard of anyone ‘dying’ so many times and the only reason I’m here is because of them. 
"The hospital was brilliant and I owe them everything." A top team at Worcestershire Royal Hospital saved Ray's life another 26 times over 24 hours (Photo: SWNS.com) 
Ray had been an enthusiastic member of Hartshill Strollers, a club that arranges walking football tournaments for the over 50s, 60s, 70s and even 80s. 
He felt a sharp pain in his chest but thought he was just dehydrated and had a drink before playing on. 
But moments later he collapsed and paramedics were eventually called on the advice of an off-duty nurse. Ray with his pals at the Hartshill Strollers walking football team (Photo: Facebook) 
Ray's family, including partner Jo Stokes, 50, sister Jayne, 49, brother Robert, 51, and his three children, rushed to support him in hospital. 
The team, led by Dr Deepak Goyal and Dr David Smith, kept Ray alive despite his repeated heart attacks through the night and into the next day. 
Thanks to their determination and expertise, Ray eventually stabilised and is on his way to recovery. 
He lost 20 per cent of his heart's function as a result of his ordeal, and is taking it easy with a few strolls each day. 
But Aston Villa fan Ray said his ultimate aim is to get back on the pitch playing football one day. Like us on Facebook
